displayed_text: Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - is open for discussion is to treat this as if it was a prostate cancer and see if it goes away. Patient: Okay, so - Doctor: And if it does, and in retrospect, because if we give you a hormone therapy, for example and it’s a gist, it will not increase sized at all. Patient: Correct. Doctor: If it’s a hormone therapy and it’s prostate cancer, you know it’s gonna disappear or decrease by ninety percent within the first few months. Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal? Doctor: Well, I was gonna, I was gonna talk to you about that. Um… Patient: Right. Doctor: I think it it probably - some type of hormone therapy is probably gonna be in your near future. It might not be the immediate future, but I think sooner rather than later given that we’ve tried this sort of outside-the-box non-hormonal type of therapy and it hasn’t really you know worked as well as we had hoped, the next step I think given that the PSA is rising and given that this lymph node is increasing, I do happen to believe it’s prostate cancer would lead me to the conclusion that hormone therapy is probably the next best thing to do. Patient: Now with hormonal therapy, um it is not a cure. It’s just a uh–. Doctor: That’s correct… It’s - Patient: Okay, so it’s not a cure. The only thing it would be doing is slowing down the progress of the, it would slow down the -

Patient: I know, I, yeah, no, I’d like to go and see if I have it or not because that would be another option I could possibly go to Europe or wherever and have them do it, if I know it’s going to help. If it’s not going to help, I don’t want to go over there. Doctor: No. I agree. So, but that would mean you would sign up for the study if they’re going to do the scan. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So you’re okay with that? Patient: Yeah. Yeas. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Uh, there’s no penalty if I don’t, is there? Doctor: If you don’t go on-? Patient: If I do go there and don’t go on it? Where, where will I get the shots at if I um stay here? Doctor: Here. Patient: Oh, here? Doctor: Yes. In the hospital. You just, uh, or downstairs in radiation, sorry.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Now, we’ve probably told you this before including me, myself, telling you this. That when you are taking an experimental drug, that’s not a hormonal therapy, in this case it’s . Uh, just because the PSA is going up, doesn’t necessarily mean the drug is not working, although when the PSA is dropping, we certainly always interpret that as a good sign. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And, and your PSA over the last three months has continued to go up. Uh, and so that’s one thing. Uh, on the other hand, you know, the scan that you had on August the first and August the second showed that the cancer seems to be relatively stable. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The thing that has concerned us before was that you were getting this sort of worsening bone pain in the left thigh bone and the lower spine and the left ribcage, which sounds like you’re still having those to some degree. They don’t sound as constant. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth.

Family Member: Okay, good. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If we can get him looked at it’s… Doctor: Well how about any, how is the pain in the neck? Did that flare up? Patient: No. That’s gone. Doctor: That’s been gone too? Patient: Yeah it’s been gone. Doctor: It didn’t come back in between at all? Patient: No. That was a one-week episode. Doctor: Can you move your neck? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Side to side? Does that bring on pain?

Family Member: He does see a chiropractor. Doctor: Okay. Patient: On occasion I do. Plus I started swinging golf clubs again and mowed the lawn. Family Member: That explains it. Patient: So I got stuff going on here. Doctor: After next week it’s gonna be much more in pain then if you’re gonna make him work hard. (Laughs) Family Member: No, I don’t make him work hard. It’s me. He’ll say oh you missed a spot and it’s like oh okay. Family Member: It’s okay. I get him to dust. He gets the easy stuff. Doctor: Alright. Family Member: I’ll do the rest. Doctor: Oh my gosh. You have a busy week. Okay so let me have S___ come in then. We’ll get that – all of those testing going. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t combine Zytiga and the radium together. I specifically say that because there have been patients who have had leftover pills and yeah. Hey, the things going up after I try the pill. But actually, when they combined it people did worse so that study has already been done and people got more bone fractures so that’s no fun. So, I just tell everybody, you know, you’ve had it before. You can go on it after but not at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s actually an absolute no-go black box. Okay, good. Family Member: What does the PSA going up, what does it, is it gonna cause it to spread? Doctor: It might really. No. But it might, again it’s not a reflection of what’s happening. It’s almost like oh, the ship’s sinking and the rats are all kind of jumping off. I’ve had patients that go from twenty to one hundred to five hundred and you’re like, oh, but they actually feel better. So, like it doesn’t match you. Family Member: It’s not the biggest thing because people always ask you what’s your PSA. Doctor: Yeah, no, just say oh, I’m on a treatment where the PSA actually goes up and like, you know, we have a vaccine therapy that that happens but Xofigo for sure and we know that because actually one of the fellows who is now faculty wrote a paper on our collective experience when we first started doing it and Patient: Alright. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors.

Family Member: Just what we need. Patient: Yeah as little as possible. Doctor: Yeah, so I looked at all the other stuff that your doctor wanted and you know all of that is fine unless we put you on something else if we decide to go with any treatment then Patient: It would have to be approved through, yeah. Doctor: we may have to take a relook and… Family Member: That’s why we made you the copies… Doctor: Yeah. Thank you. Family Member: You can see all the ingredients. Doctor: For now you can use it, but then I will compare the ingredients to make sure it doesn’t affect anything. Patient: I think I’ll just wait before I start adding that stuff on there because some of it’s a little pricy. Doctor: You need a few weeks. Oh yeah. Family Member: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for 1 year or more: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for 1 year or more

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Prefer to self-describe (please specify): What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Prefer to self-describe (please specify)

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: Sorry for the neutral answers in the last questions but It's sort of a loaded question as every doctor is different

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. Well, I, you know, I, I totally live, chemo would be logistically a problem. You know? I mean I’m, you know, I kind of dread it. I do. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I kind of knew it was coming but uh. What do you think the duration of that? Doctor: Of the treatment? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So on a trial, it’s for eight treatments. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, you know, numb hands and feet, but in general the trial allows you to do that and then if you’re not on the vitamin C everybody starts to get the vitamin C.

Patient: And my PSA wasn’t on the sheet. Do you guys have a number on that? Doctor: It’s not back. Did you do it yesterday? No today. Patient: We did labs today. Doctor: Oh, okay. No it’s not back yet then. I’ll take a look and let you know but Patient: Okay. Doctor: If it’s back. Family Member: Next Friday we’ll be back to plan out the next step and… Doctor: That’s what I’m thinking. Family Member: The tests should be back by then? Doctor: Yeah, but you know what just for now wait for a phone call and I’ll have S call you as soon as we get the results so we can sort of plan better for that Friday. Family Member: So it’s just a one day in and out thing? Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Show me how is the shoulder doing? Patient: Oh the shoulders are good.

Patient: No. Family Member: So what about, okay you said radiation on the prostate. Doctor: I didn’t say that. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I’m saying that may be an option. Family Member: May be an option. Doctor: Because where we’ve been you know we’ve been talking about you know hormones is the base layer and then do we add chemotherapy on top of that? And then we talked to you about the clinical trial – Patient: Right. Doctor: - which is you know potentially adding a third drug on top of it. Patient: Right. Doctor: So three punches versus two punches. Patient: Right.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll either know today or they may have to call you once they put you on the schedule. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: And then how long after that scope thing? Doctor: Usually then he’ll pick a date so. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: He’ll probably tell you on that day – Family Member: Uh huh. Doctor: When you’re likely to get… Do you have anything going on that you want us to work around then let them know at that time? Patient: That we probably can’t change. Doctor: Okay. Patient: The doctors you know.

Family Member: Will he need to have somebody come with him? Doctor: Uh, no, but how is he going to – do you have transportation arrangements made? Family Member: He drives. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: He drives. Shit. J__ drives everywhere. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Is for the biopsy that we will need to do – Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new- Family Member: Yeah. Right. Doctor: I would- Family Member: You want somebody here. Doctor: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you.

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. So it was- Doctor: Wow. That’s quite- you did way more than just a safari. That’s a lot. Family Member: Oh, yeah. Patient: Oh, way, way. Doctor: So how was Cape Town and Johannesburg? Are they nice cities? Family Member: Oh, yes, beautiful. That’s what we said. Everybody always talks about Johannesburg because it kind of reminded you of New York City. And nobody never said anything about Cape Town, and it’s just beautiful, the beaches and everything, like, wow. Doctor: Because they were having a drought there for a long time. Family Member: Yeah. In certain areas, it still is, like the parks, they don’t, they have like, use the, uh, sanitary lotion and stuff on your hands and toilets don’t flush. Doctor: So when you were like in Cape Town. What did you guys do when you were there? Because it’s like summer there now, isn’t it? Family Member: Yeah. It getting to be summer there. Yeah. The weather was very nice. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Did you like go to the beach or you just-?

Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Family Member: She was like… Doctor: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork Family Member: Okay. Doctor: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication. Family Member: I think that’s a good idea. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies. Patient: Oh, oh…

Family Member: Okay. I heard Doctor: Well, BRCA2 also puts you at risk for melanoma, so. (pause) Patient: Well, I’ve got a lot of skin tags. So. I, uh, I, I, all I was, I was just bringing that up because I thought that would be something you would probably be interested in, too. Doctor: I am interested in that. It’s kind of, um, I don’t know if it’s because Nicotinamide somehow absorbs sunlight or how it would work? Patient: Well. I don’t know. Look at the alien show. Maybe you can figure it out. Doctor: Well. They’re all green, so they have a different problem. So. Family Member: They have different skin. Doctor: Yeah. (laughs) Doctor: Yeah, that part of it is funny because --- Alright, April seventeenth, the big day, we’ll get your PSA test. Are you, where do you do your PSA test? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Right here? Family Member: Uh.
